posts.name: Neil
posts.cooked:
HI, Our team is currently trying to code swerve and we keep running into this problem were the module keep taking extra rotations to get to the desired position when trying to rotate. When we tried to increase our kp value for our turrning pid loop it keeps oscillating. We dont know if it is an issue with the pid or something else.

thorkiller35/ASwerve2023 (github.com)

Video: 20231016_193646.mp4 - Google Drive

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Did you enable PID wrapping? Not sure what encoder you’re using, but you’d want to tell your PID controller that 0 and 360 degrees are the samr position and it is allowed to “wrap around”.

The method you call to do this depends on what PID controller you’re using, onboard (REV vs CTRE) or WPILib.

posts.name: Shoumik
posts.cooked: I’m a part of Neil’s team. We use CANcoders, NEOs, and a navX.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 8866 | Jack of Some Trades, Master of Some

posts.custom_user_title: 8866 | Jack of Some Trades, Master of Some

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Ah, then seeing as a Spark Max can’t use a CANcoder directly, you’re probably using a software PID controller.

In which case you wanna call PIDController.enableContinuousInput(minInput, maxInput)

posts.name: Neil
posts.cooked:
I’m pretty sure that we are using the Wplib one.

posts.cooked: Did you zero your modules? Also you can look to other teams that use your modules to get good PID values for your configuration of swerve module and motor choice.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Posted above. Also as another user said, check if you’re optimizing your swerve module states. Your swerve modules shouldn’t need to ever turn more than 90 degrees.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
You’ve already done that, in the code you posted last. It appears you’re using radians, so you’ve told the PID controller that -π and +π are the same.

Are you guys converting units correctly from the CANcoder? From it’s native units to radians?

posts.name: Neil
posts.cooked:
I’m pretty sure we are.

posts.name: Neil
posts.cooked: The robot slowly turns to the correct position but then sometimes it overshoots and has to backtrack. This happens a couple of seaconds affter we give the joystick input and it is not clean.

posts.name: Jp
posts.cooked: Maybe the Kp is too high? and the acceleration too low

posts.name: Neil
posts.cooked:
When we decrease the Kp it barely moves and when you talking about acceleration do you mean this

image 995×41 4.43 KB

image 995×41 4.43 KB

image 995×41 4.43 KB

Log your absolute encoder angles and see what happens during these otherwise erratic motions. Also see what happens when manually twisting the wheels.

Double-check your PID Controller setpoint and reference to ensure they’re the right units. Does the CANCoder output degrees?

posts.name: Neil
posts.cooked: They do output degrees but we chnage them to radians. It turns to the right position but it is kinda slow. So I dont think it is a setpoint issue. You can see the issue in this video 20231016_193646.mp4 - Google Drive
